results.title: The Car and the city
results.creator_credit: Boris Holtzman and United Nations Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Man builds - man destroys”.
The automobile is a serious polluter of the air and a major interruption to urban activities. So planners are looking at ways to change or limit the use of the conventional automobile in large cities, and to ease mass transit flow. Features William Lear’s 1975 steam car, a representative of the US EPA and John Esposito from the Ralph Nader Center for Study of Responsive Law, and Helen Leavitt, author of “Super-highway, super hoax”.

results.title: Among the living
results.creator_credit: Osborn Segerberg and United Nations Television
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Man builds - man destroys”.
Raises the question of whether there is such a thing as an “optimum” world population, while looking closely at the town of Huntington on Long Island, one of the many satellite communities surrounding New York City. Presents the views on population of such noted authorities as Paul Ehrlich, Barry Commoner, Philip Hauser, Alan Guttmacher and Lincoln Day. Hosted by Don Pringle.

results.title: The Formula factor
results.creator_credit: Rosalind Farber and Canadian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Man Alive”.
Documents the problems and dangers of infant formula marketing and bottle-feeding in the third world. Highlights the efforts of government health workers and church organisations to challenge the practices of multinational corporations who are irresponsible and somewhat aggressive in their promotion of formula and their chase for profits. Focuses on Nestles, the world’s largest producer of baby formula. Presented by Roy Bonisteel. Suitable for upper secondary and tertiary levels.

results.title: The Palestinian guerrilla = The Terrorists
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Man Alive”.
This program, commonly known as “The Terrorists”, traces the historical origins and growth of Palestinian militancy, and examines two incidents in detail - the multiple hijacking at Dawson’s Field, Lebanon, in 1970, and the Schonan Castle incident in Austria involving a Jewish transit camp. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Gale is dead
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Man Alive”.
Gale was 19, beautiful, intelligent, had much to offer and everything to live for. However she was a drug addict, and was recently found dead. She had been shifted in and out of 14 institutions throughout her life and believed no-one cared for her. Reporter Harold Williamson talks to people in Gale’s life and the film asks if Gale need have died, and tries to show that there may be other Gales for whom it is not too late to help. Letters read by Anna Frankel.

results.title: The Biggest epidemic of our times. Pt. 2
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Man Alive”.
The second of two programs in which doctors, police and accident investigation teams powerfully demonstrate the need for greater care on the roads. This episode focuses on the problems of motorcyclists and the safety regulations of helmets.

results.title: The Biggest epidemic of our times. Pt. 1
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Man Alive”.
The first of two programs in which doctors, police and accident investigation teams powerfully demonstrate the need for greater care on the roads. This episode presents the statistics on British road accidents and discusses the legislation on seat belts.

results.title: Trouble in Paradise
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Man Alive”.
Many people would regard Switzerland as an earthly paradise. Why is it then that young people have been rioting in Zurich? Jack Pizzey examines the theory that the price the Swiss pay for their affluence is a sham democracy where the real power lies with big business and that the country’s image of Red Cross altruism hides ruthless exploitation of the Third World.

results.title: David
results.creator_credit: Tom Kelly and Canadian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Man Alive”.
David is a young actor with Down’s Syndrome, chosen to portray a mentally handicapped adolescent in a Canadian television play. Points out society’s unwillingness to accept potential from those with Down’s. David speaks about his condition to a school class and is shown skating, swimming, jogging and cycling, and interacting with family and friends. Suitable for middle and upper secondary and tertiary levels.
